title.narrative: PPDP Youth employment- RUTA MOTOR Colombia 2018-2023

description.narrative:
Programmet Ruta Motor är den andra fasen av ett program som Sverige har givit stöd till sedan november 2014. Bidraget syftar till att bryta intergenerations-cykeln av fattigdom för utsatta unga genom Offentligt-privat partnerskap som förser relevant arbetskraft till arbetsmarknaden. De tre avsedda målen är: 1; förbättra anställningsförhållanden för 1000 utsatta unga män och kvinnor från Bogotá, Medellin, Cali och Valledupar, 2; förbättra deltagandet av privata företag och deras koordinering med relevanta offentliga institutioner, 3; stärka det offentliga erbjudandet om yrkesmässig träning och högre utbildning för att kunna svara till arbetsmarknadens efterfrågan.
Genomförandepartnern är Neme Fundation som också genomförde den första fasen av programmet. Neme Fundation har undertecknat ett tidigare avtal med Svenska Ambassaden och har visat, sen 2014, överenstämmelse med avtalets förhållanden. Granskningsrapporten har också visat en stark finansiell förvaltning och internt kontrollsystem.
Den totala budgeten för fyra år är 20,5 miljoner SEK och det är föreslaget att Sverige bidrar med 10 miljoner SEK vilket representerar 47 % av den totala budgeten. Fortsättningsvis bidrar SENA med 24 %, Neme Foundation 10 %, Holding Group A 9 %, CHM Mining 68 %, Foundation Future 21 % och Plan International 0,4 %. Aktivitetsperioden kommer vara från första juli 2018 till 31 december 2021.

The program Ruta Motor in the second phase of a program that has been supported by Sweden since November 2014. The contribution aims at breaking the inter-generational cycle of poverty for young vulnerable people through a public private partnership that provide relevant labor force to the market. The three intended outputs are, first, improving conditions for employment of 1000 vulnerable young men and women from Bogota, Medellin, Cali and Valledupar; second, improving participation of private companies and their coordination with relevant public institutions and, finally, to strengthen the public offer of vocational training and higher education in order that responds to the labor demand. This program also contributes to the UN SC resolution 2250,2015 as it aims at preventing young people from the effects of conflict, including displaced and prevent their connection with armed groups and therefore is aligned with the Swedish cooperation strategy with Colombia.
The implementing partner is the Neme Foundation that has been also implementing the first phase of the program. The Neme Foundation has signed a previous agreement with the Embassy of Sweden and has demonstrated since 2014 compliance with the agreement conditions. The audit reports have also shown strong financial management and internal control system.
The total budget for four years is 20,5 MSEK and it is proposed that Sweden contributes with 10MSEK that represents 47% of the total budget, SENA 24%, Neme Foundation 10%, Holding Group A 9%, CHM Mining 8%, Foundation Future 21 1% and Plan International 0,4%. The activity period will be from July 1st 2018 to December 31, 2021.

This contribution aims in the long term at breaking the inter-generational cycle of poverty for young vulnerable people through a public private partnership that provide relevant labor force to the market. The three intended outputs are, first, improving conditions for employment of 1000 vulnerable young men and women from Bogota, Medellin, Cali and Valledupar; second, improving participation of private companies and their coordination with relevant public institutions and, finally, to strengthen the public offer of vocational training and higher education in order that responds to the labor demand.

description.narrative:
This program, that aims to improve employment conditions for vulnerable young men and women, was also affected in 2020 by the Covid 19 global pandemic that resulted in the Colombian economy suffering a fall of 6.8% in GDP. The lockdown measures affected many enterprises and the unemployment rate rose from 10.5% in 2019 to 15.9% in 2020, with women and young people being the most affected by unemployment. The Neme foundation took different measures during 2020 to counteract the problems brought on by the Covid-19 crisis and the impact on participants and companies as explained below.
The Neme Foundation reported progress along the three axes that form the public private development partnership: 1. The young participants 2. The private companies and 3. The public sector.
First, as regards young participants, together with the 822 young participants that started vocational training in SENA in 2019, 141 additional young participants started in 2020, making a total of 963 participants (45% women). The last group of participants to join had to receive 100% virtual training due to the lockdown measures and the consequent closure of SENA installations.
These participants faced huge challenges as the majority did not have the technical means (e.g. laptops, tablets, stable internet connection) to receive virtual training. To overcome these problems, the Neme Foundation provided support to 593 participants with the provision of internet connection and 150 support packages to cover the basic needs of food and housing. The project promotes youth empowerment, so these are temporary subsidies. All participants also received permanent psychosocial support during the whole year either by internet or through phone calls.
All participants had a choice of 27 different programs related to the automotive sector and administrative and logistic training, useful for every sector. Even though the program has increased the inclusion of women in programs usually favored by men (such as auto electrical and electronic maintenance; vehicle and industrial machinery maintenance or painting), women still prefer programs such as administrative assistance (75% of women), financial or commercial operations (80% of women), human resources (86% of women) and sales (70% of women).
By the end of 2020, 29 participants were still receiving vocation training; 311 had started internships in different companies but 47 of their contracts had to be suspended due to the pandemic; 60 had finished training and are looking for internships; 164 had ended internships and are looking for jobs; 35 wanted to continue formal education; 43 had started employment but continue to be accompanied by the program; 2 had started their own entrepreneurships; 71 had successfully finished the program with formal labour contracts of more than 3 months, 37 postponed participating in the program; 11 left the program but had continued with training; and 163 had dropped out of the program. It is important to highlight that the lowest dropout rate was in Cesar (1.4%) due to a combination of the low opportunities for young people as well the interest of being part of mining companies that pay higher salaries than other sectors.
The dropout rate increased from 8.7% in 2019 to 16.9% in 2020. The main causes for them dropping out was: lack of interest in technical training (29); followed by those young people with a low academic performance and sanctions by SENA (24); participants who prioritized work over study (18); participants experiencing difficulties with the academic workload (16); unjustified absences and sanctions by SENA (8); family conflicts (6); health problems (7); disciplinary sanctions by SENA (7); need to look after family member(s) with health problems (5); participants that moved to other cities (4); participant(s) with different expectations (5); other situations such as: volunteering for military service, starting technology training, high-risk pregnancy, etc (34).
Secondly, in order to increase the commitment of private companies, during 2020 the Neme Foundation contacted 242 companies from the automotive, mining and textile sectors and held virtual meetings with 49 of them to raise awareness about the advantages of being part of the partnership and to share profiles of participants. In addition, the Neme Foundation had a dialogue with business guilds such as the Colombian Association of enterprises (ANDI is the Spanish acronym) to present the program’s objectives and results. Despite the interest shown by many companies, their employment needs were reduced due to the Covid 19 economic consequences and between March and September 2020 the economic contraction also resulted in the suspension of 134 internships.
The companies, that are part of the holding Group Chaid Neme Hermanos and CHM Mining, are financing part of the project and have guaranteed internships for 81 participants. In addition, other mining companies in the region of Cesar are aware of the program and have shown interest in recruiting young participants. CHM mining has sponsored 60 participants in Cesar during 2020 and will sponsor 30 additional participants in 2021.
Finally, as regards the public sector, due to the change of the local governments in January 2020, new contacts had to be established with new secretaires of economic development in Bogota, Medellin and Cali, as well as new contacts with the offices of local mayors in five municipalities in Cesar. However due to the pandemic, the local authorities are more interested in including new young people than to provide support to the current participants.
As mentioned in the last conclusion on performance, the formal MOU with SENA was only signed in June 2019. The change in leadership has resulted in a year’s delay in planned activities and additional costs for psychosocial accompaniment. Only 54% of participants (471) entered SENA through the MoU and 53 sponsored by CHM mining in Cesar. The other 45% (439) entered through the general admission invitation. Nevertheless, during 2020, the dialogue with the Directorate of Professional Training and the Directorate of Welfare has improved and 236 functionaries participated in virtual meetings to discuss an exchange of experiences and lessons learnt.
The alliance with the Colombian Family Welfare Institute (ICBF), that was signed in 2018 to include participants from the Adolescent Criminal Responsibility System, continued in 2019 and 2020 with the inclusion of 171 participants from that system in Bogota.
